participants.name: Janet Dougherty
participants.paper: Machiavelli ’ s Knives Michael Hoffapuir, UATX The capstone panel of our CWC puts in tension ancient and modern political philosophy. Dr. Frank

participants.name: Pagano (St. John ’ s College
participants.affiliation: Annapolis) considers antiquity as a project articulated by Herdotus,

participants.name: Sophocles
participants.affiliation: and Aeschylus. Dr. Rachel Mackey (Hudson Institute) articulates Aristotle ’ s understanding
participants.paper: of the fundamental conditions for political life and asks whether the classical notion of politics still exists,

participants.name: or indeed can exist
participants.affiliation: in the modern age. Dr. J. Michael Hoffpauir (University of Austin) explores in
participants.paper: Machiavelli ’ s mentions of “ knives ” his modern conceptions of fortune, god, cruelty, and the divine.

participants.name: Janet Dougherty (St. John ’ s College
participants.affiliation: Annapolis) concludes with a book that bridges ancient and modern
participants.paper: thought, Montesquieu ’ s Persian Letters . She inquire s about the relationship between the modern scientific method and ancient philosophy ’ s quest for self - knowledge, as well as between despotism and enlightened government. Taken together, these presentations aim to present ancient and modern conce ptions of politics and philosophy and ask what students of politics can learn by putting them in dialogue with one another. Panel members will respond to one another.

participants.name: Richard Van Weelden
participants.paper: This panel examines how organizations, money, and geography shape American politics. Hall and Sun document the rise of corporate policy teams, showing that firms increasingly invest more in internal political expertise than in traditional lobbying. Berry and Fowler trace the shifting geography of economic productivity and partisan alignment, highlighting how the new political economy of place reshapes distributive politics. Fouirnaies shows how interest group endorsements tilt primary elections, underscorin g how organized groups channel support to favored candidates. Finally, Buisseret presents a formal model of elections in which the incentives of campaigns to raise money from small donors leads to polarized platforms. Together, these papers reveal the diverse ways in which money, expertise, geography, and group support shape contemporary American politics, offering new perspectives on the anatomy of influence beyond the ballot box.
